description: Recorded since 1665; either directly or via Middle English refreschement, from Old French refrescher (12th century; modern French rafraîchir), itself from re- (“again”) + fresche (“fresh”) (modern French frais; from a Germanic source, cognate with Old High German frisc, modern German frisch, Dutch fris, etc.)

entries.meaning: The action of refreshing; a means of restoring strength, energy or vigour.

examples: All refreshments will be provided by the hosts.
